slides.title: Chapter 1 — General Issues
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Scope

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Safety Management System (SMS) provides a structured and documented framework to ensure safe, efficient, and compliant operations across all Company activities. It aligns with the ISM Code, MLC 2006, and ISO 9001, promoting continual improvement in health, safety, environmental, and quality performance.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ System Structure and Operation

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The SMS is based on adequate resources, effective procedures, and proactive risk management. It includes event reporting, preventive maintenance, and periodic evaluations through internal audits and management reviews to ensure ongoing suitability and improvement.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Application Field and Distribution

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The SMS applies to all Company functions, ashore and onboard, including every vessel under management. Controlled copies are maintained electronically and distributed under HSQE supervision, ensuring that personnel always have access to current and approved procedures.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Working Language and Communication

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: English is designated as the official communication language between Company offices and ships, and the common working language onboard. This standard ensures clarity, consistent interpretation of instructions, and efficient communication across multinational crews.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Context and Compliance Framework

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The SMS considers the Company’s internal and external operational context, as well as the needs of stakeholders and regulatory obligations. It integrates these factors to maintain compliance with international and national requirements while supporting safe and sustainable operations.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 1 introduces the structure and purpose of the Safety Management System. It outlines its scope, resources, communication standards, and compliance principles, establishing a solid foundation for safety, quality, and environmental performance throughout the Company.

chapters.title: Chapter 10 — Maintenance of the Ship and Equipment

slides.title: Chapter 10 — Maintenance of the Ship and Equipment
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Ship Maintenance Policy

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company maintains all vessels in full compliance with international and national regulations, classification rules, and industry standards. Maintenance ensures reliability of systems, minimizes breakdowns, and sustains safe, cost-effective operations at all times.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Planned Maintenance System (PMS)

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: A structured PMS schedules and records all maintenance tasks for critical machinery, deck, and safety systems. Jobs are planned based on manufacturer guidance, Class requirements, and operational feedback, ensuring timely completion and traceable documentation.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Responsibilities and Control

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Master and Chief Engineer are responsible for implementing the PMS onboard, while shore technical staff monitor performance, analyze equipment trends, and plan corrective actions. The system ensures that ship and shore teams cooperate seamlessly in maintenance management.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Equipment and System Guidelines

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Detailed procedures cover maintenance for engines, pumps, piping, electrical systems, mooring gear, firefighting appliances, and hull coatings. Each activity follows approved instructions, ensuring safety, environmental protection, and consistent performance standards.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Inspections, Repairs, and Continuous Improvement

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Regular shipboard inspections and condition assessments identify defects, triggering timely repairs. Drydocking, class surveys, and audits verify compliance and system integrity. Lessons learned are incorporated into updated procedures for continual improvement of fleet maintenance.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 10 establishes the Company’s structured system for ship and equipment maintenance. It integrates planned maintenance, inspections, and repair procedures to ensure reliability, compliance, and sustained operational safety throughout the vessel’s life cycle.

slides.title: Chapter 11 — Document / Data Control
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Scope

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: This chapter ensures that all SMS documents and records are properly reviewed, approved, distributed, and controlled. It establishes procedures for identifying, maintaining, and updating documents to prevent the use of obsolete or invalid information.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Identification and Issue Control

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: All SMS documents include clear identification data: Company name, chapter, title, issue and revision numbers, dates, and page numbering. Each document is reviewed during Management Review Committee meetings to incorporate new requirements or procedural improvements.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Distribution and Change Management

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Controlled copies of the SMS are distributed to relevant personnel ashore and onboard through secure channels. Any change to procedures or forms must be reviewed, approved, and recorded. Obsolete documents are promptly removed to maintain data integrity.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Records, Storage, and Retention

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Records must remain legible, traceable, and readily retrievable. They are stored securely in both paper and electronic form, with defined retention periods according to Company policy. Disposal of expired records is documented and approved.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Electronic Systems and Certificates

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Electronic Certificates and Record Books (e-Certificates, ERBs) are maintained where approved by the Flag Administration. Electronic documentation follows strict data protection, classification, and software control standards to ensure system reliability and security.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 11 defines the control and management of SMS documents and data. It ensures that all information remains accurate, traceable, and secure throughout its lifecycle, supporting operational consistency, regulatory compliance, and continuous improvement.

slides.title: Chapter 12 — Verification, Review, and Evaluation
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Overview

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company ensures continuous verification, review, and evaluation of its Safety Management System (SMS) through planned audits, inspections, and assessments. These activities confirm that established procedures are properly implemented and remain effective across all operations.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Internal Audits and Verification

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Internal audits are conducted both ashore and onboard to evaluate compliance with SMS requirements and international standards. Findings are recorded, and corrective actions are followed up to ensure that non-conformities are promptly addressed and prevented from recurring.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Specialized Audits and Assessments

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Company performs additional audits covering navigation, cargo, mooring, engineering, contractors, and manning agents. These assessments verify operational standards, equipment reliability, and personnel competence under Company procedures and regulatory expectations.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Remote and Unscheduled Audits

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Unscheduled or remote audits may be carried out in response to incidents, deficiencies, or special requests from management. Such reviews provide flexibility in monitoring performance and enable immediate feedback to maintain continuous compliance and safety performance.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Management Reviews and Continuous Improvement

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Results from all audits and verifications are analyzed during Masters’ Reviews, Safety Meetings, and Management Review Committee (MRC) sessions. Performance data and audit trends are evaluated to improve the SMS, allocate resources, and define measurable objectives for improvement.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 12 establishes the Company’s audit and review system for verifying the effectiveness of its Safety Management System. It ensures structured internal audits, periodic reviews, and management evaluations that drive continual improvement and operational excellence.

slides.title: Chapter 13 — Management of Change (MoC)
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Objectives

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Management of Change (MoC) process ensures that all modifications within the Company or vessels are implemented under controlled and authorized conditions. It prevents unplanned disruptions, ensures regulatory compliance, and minimizes operational and safety risks.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Identification of Change

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Changes may arise from new regulations, technical improvements, vessel acquisitions or disposals, operational adjustments, or personnel restructuring. Each proposed change must be clearly identified, documented, and communicated for proper evaluation and control.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Evaluation and Risk Assessment

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Every proposed change is assessed for potential impacts on safety, environmental protection, quality, and resources. The evaluation process determines the level of risk, identifies mitigation measures, and confirms that no adverse effects compromise ship or shore operations.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Approval and Implementation

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Authorized managers review and approve change requests before implementation. The DPA or responsible department coordinates actions, updates relevant SMS documentation, and ensures that affected personnel are trained and briefed on new requirements.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Monitoring and Continuous Review

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: After implementation, each change is monitored and verified for effectiveness. Lessons learned are analyzed and incorporated into future revisions of procedures to enhance control, consistency, and continuous improvement within the SMS framework.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 13 establishes the Company’s Management of Change system, ensuring that all operational or organizational changes are properly evaluated, authorized, and monitored. It promotes structured risk control, compliance, and continual improvement across all activities.

chapters.title: Chapter 14 — Risk Assessment (RA) and Risk Management (RM)

slides.title: Chapter 14 — Risk Assessment (RA) and Risk Management (RM)
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Scope

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company applies a structured Risk Assessment (RA) and Risk Management (RM) process to identify, evaluate, and control hazards that could affect health, safety, environment, or operations. All activities are assessed to ensure that risks are reduced to the As Low As Reasonably Practicable (ALARP) level.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Responsibilities and Team Structure

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: All employees ashore and onboard must identify potential hazards and request an RA when needed. RAs are performed by competent RA Teams consisting of trained officers and staff. The DPA, Managers, and Masters oversee the process and ensure that results are reviewed, approved, and implemented effectively.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Risk Assessment Procedure

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The process includes hazard identification, risk analysis, and implementation of control measures. The risk is determined by the product of frequency and consequence (R = F × C). Each RA defines preventive and mitigation measures to minimize exposure and residual risk, ensuring operational safety.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Approval and Follow-Up

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Risk Assessments are approved according to their category and residual risk level. Routine and medium-risk RAs are approved onboard or ashore, while high-risk or non-routine assessments require higher management review. All actions are tracked, documented, and verified until closure.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Review and Continuous Improvement

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: RAs are reviewed during Management Review Committee (MRC) meetings or when significant operational changes occur. The DPA maintains the RA library, ensuring all documents remain current and reflect lessons learned from incidents, audits, or new regulatory developments.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 14 establishes the Company’s formal system for Risk Assessment and Risk Management. It defines responsibilities, procedures, and approval processes ensuring all operational hazards are systematically identified, controlled, and reviewed for continuous improvement.

chapters.title: Chapter 15 — New Acquisitions and Shipbuilding Projects

slides.title: Chapter 15 — New Acquisitions and Shipbuilding Projects
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Scope

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: This chapter provides procedures for acquiring new or second-hand vessels, managing newbuilding projects, and releasing ships from management. It ensures that all preparatory actions are completed safely and that associated risks are identified, assessed, and controlled.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Responsibilities and Planning

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Management oversees due diligence, contractual arrangements, and compliance verification for each new project. Responsibilities include confirming vessel condition, reviewing documentation, and coordinating with Class, Flag, and makers to ensure smooth delivery and operation.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Integration of Newly Acquired Ships

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: For second-hand vessels, the Company verifies technical condition, equipment functionality, and SMS familiarization. Officers and crew receive full induction on Company policies, reporting tools, and safety systems before assuming operational responsibility.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Newbuilding and Quality Control

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: For newbuildings, the Company supervises the design, construction, and trials under approved plans. Quality control covers inspection, testing, calibration, and adherence to standards at shipyards, subcontractors, and vendor facilities to ensure specification compliance.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Post-Delivery and Warranty Management

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: After delivery, the vessel enters service under Company management following final verification and documentation checks. The warranty period is monitored to track performance, resolve deficiencies, and confirm full operational readiness.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 15 establishes Company procedures for ship acquisition, construction, and delivery. It ensures proper evaluation, risk management, familiarization, and quality control from planning to post-delivery, maintaining operational safety and compliance.

slides.title: Chapter 16 — Quality Management
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Context

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company’s Quality Management System (QMS) aligns with ISO 9001 and forms an integral part of the SMS. It ensures that all activities meet customer, statutory, and regulatory requirements through a structured Plan–Do–Check–Act (PDCA) approach. The scope, exclusions, and control boundaries are defined within the Company’s SMS framework.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Leadership and Responsibilities

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Top Management demonstrates commitment by defining policies, objectives, and responsibilities for all departments. It ensures sufficient resources, qualified personnel, and effective communication across ship and shore teams. Customer satisfaction and continual improvement remain the core management focus.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Risk, Opportunity, and Objective Planning

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Company identifies risks and opportunities affecting service delivery and records them in the Risk and Opportunities Register. Quality objectives are measurable and reviewed periodically to ensure operational performance, efficiency, and compliance with contractual and regulatory expectations.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Resources, Competence, and Communication

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Quality performance relies on trained, competent personnel supported by adequate infrastructure and technology. Regular training, awareness programs, and communication ensure personnel understand the Quality Policy, their roles, and the potential impacts of non-conformance on safety and service reliability.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Performance Evaluation and Improvement

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Internal audits, management reviews, and customer feedback form the backbone of continuous improvement. Results are analyzed to identify non-conformities, initiate corrective actions, and enhance customer satisfaction. Outsourced services are monitored to maintain consistency and control of all quality-related processes.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 16 establishes the Company’s Quality Management framework in line with ISO 9001. It defines leadership, risk planning, communication, and improvement processes ensuring that all services meet customer expectations and regulatory requirements through continual evaluation and control.

slides.title: Chapter 17 — Contractors Management
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Objective

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: This chapter defines procedures for the qualification, selection, evaluation, and monitoring of all Contractors engaged by the Company. It ensures that all third parties perform their duties safely, effectively, and in compliance with the Company’s HSQE and operational standards.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Responsibilities and Oversight

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Managers and Superintendents set evaluation criteria, review contracts, and maintain the Approved Contractors List. The Master and Safety Officer ensure that onboard Contractors receive safety induction, participate in work-planning meetings, and comply with the Company’s operational and safety policies.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Contractor Qualification and Approval

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Prequalification assesses each Contractor’s certifications, HSQE policies, equipment standards, and past performance. Only those demonstrating compliance with ISO 9001, ISO 14001, and safety standards are approved. Unlisted Contractors may only be used with prior management authorization.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Performance Monitoring and Feedback

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Contractor performance is monitored both ashore and onboard. Masters provide feedback reports covering safety, quality, and environmental compliance. Poor performance, incidents, or non-conformities may result in corrective actions or deletion from the Approved Contractors List.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Continuous Improvement and Record Control

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Company maintains transparent contractor performance records and conducts periodic reviews. Lessons learned, complaints, and audits are used to improve contractor management, enhance HSQE performance, and ensure alignment with international and Company standards.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 17 defines how the Company selects, monitors, and evaluates Contractors. It establishes qualification criteria, approval processes, and performance reviews to ensure all contracted services meet HSQE, safety, and quality requirements.

slides.title: Chapter 18 — Third Party Ship Inspections
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Scope

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company standardizes the process for all third-party ship inspections, including Class surveys, Port State Control (PSC), P&I Club, RightShip or charterer vetting, terminal, and Flag Administration inspections. The goal is to ensure consistent preparation, coordination, and follow-up.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Responsibilities and Coordination

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Master and Chief Engineer ensure the vessel’s readiness, documentation accuracy, and crew familiarity with SMS procedures. Shore management coordinates inspection schedules, maintains records, and provides immediate assistance when findings or deficiencies arise.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Inspection Management

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: All inspections are managed using standardized checklists and planning tools. Officers conduct pre-inspection self-checks to verify compliance with statutory, class, and operational requirements. Any non-conformities are corrected before inspection to maintain full compliance.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Surveys and Certification

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Vessels maintain valid statutory and class certificates covering structure, machinery, and safety systems. Life-saving appliances, firefighting equipment, and other critical systems are inspected and certified by approved service providers according to defined intervals.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Reporting and Follow-Up

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Inspection results are reviewed by the DPA and relevant managers. Corrective actions are tracked until closure, and lessons learned are shared across the fleet. Records are archived to demonstrate compliance and support continual improvement during future inspections.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 18 establishes the Company’s system for managing all third-party inspections and certifications. It defines responsibilities, ensures preparation and coordination, and promotes continuous improvement to maintain safe and compliant ship operations.

slides.title: Chapter 19 — Purchasing
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Scope

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The purchasing system ensures that all products and services procured meet specified quality, safety, and environmental standards. All purchases are authorized through written requisitions in the Company’s ERP system to guarantee proper control and traceability.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Procurement Principles

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Purchasing relies on competitive bidding and negotiation with approved suppliers. Confidentiality is maintained at all stages, and procurement decisions are based on fitness for purpose, safety, delivery reliability, environmental compliance, and cost-effectiveness.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Responsibilities and Supplier Evaluation

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Suppliers and contractors are evaluated and approved based on their ability to meet Company standards. Performance reviews and periodic re-evaluations ensure that only reliable, compliant, and ethical suppliers remain on the Approved Vendors List.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Conflict of Interest and Ethical Conduct

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Personnel must avoid any conflict of interest in purchasing activities. Gifts or favors from suppliers are strictly prohibited. Any potential conflict must be reported immediately to the Purchasing Manager or Master to maintain transparency and integrity.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Onboard and Emergency Purchasing

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Master is not authorized to make local purchases without Company approval, except in emergencies. Emergency procurements are reported immediately with full documentation to ensure proper validation, accountability, and budget control.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 19 defines the Company’s purchasing process, emphasizing supplier qualification, ethical conduct, and strict requisition control. It ensures transparency, compliance, and value in every procurement, maintaining safety and environmental standards across all operations.

chapters.title: Chapter 2 — Company’s Policies and Management Commitment

slides.title: Chapter 2 — Company’s Policies and Management Commitment
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Mission, Vision, and Core Values

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company’s mission is to set the standards for safe and environmentally responsible sea transportation through modern, well-maintained ships and motivated personnel, targeting zero incidents.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: Its vision is to remain a leading provider of global cargo transport by promoting safety culture, embracing technology, and achieving efficiency through superior management.

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Core values define the expected behavior of all personnel and shape the Company’s professional identity.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 2️⃣ Company Policy Concept

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: All personnel must understand and apply the Company’s policies described in the SMS Appendices.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: These include principles of non-discrimination, anti-harassment, confidentiality, and responsible communication.

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Policies are posted at all Company locations and vessels, reviewed annually, and ensure that all activities ashore and onboard align with corporate objectives.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 3️⃣ Responsibilities and Management System Support

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Top Management demonstrates commitment to the SMS by establishing policies, defining objectives, and developing strategic plans to address risks and opportunities.

slides.title: Section 11
slides.text: It ensures adequate infrastructure, competent personnel, and a safe work environment both onboard and ashore.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: All employees receive SMS information in a language they understand to maintain operational conformity and safety.

slides.title: Section 13
slides.text: 4️⃣ Management Commitment and Continuous Improvement

slides.title: Section 14
slides.text: Management promotes HSQE excellence through leadership and consistent application of the SMS.

slides.title: Section 15
slides.text: It ensures supervision of all work, investigation of incidents, and open communication between ship and shore.

slides.title: Section 16
slides.text: Personnel participation and feedback are integral to achieving sustainable improvements and higher operational standards.

slides.title: Section 17
slides.text: 5️⃣ Continuous Improvement Model

slides.title: Section 18
slides.text: The Company follows a “Plan – Act – Measure – Improve” cycle.

slides.title: Section 19
slides.text: Policies define purpose and responsibilities (Plan); consistent implementation ensures effectiveness (Act); performance is monitored and evaluated (Measure); and results guide further development (Improve).

slides.title: Section 20
slides.text: This structured process delivers measurable progress and long-term efficiency.

slides.title: Section 22
slides.text: Chapter 2 describes how the Company’s mission, vision, and core values translate into clear policies, defined responsibilities, and management commitment.

slides.title: Section 23
slides.text: It explains how leadership ensures continual improvement through structured planning, performance measurement, and engagement at all organizational levels.

slides.title: Chapter 20 — Cybersecurity
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Objectives and Purpose

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Cybersecurity system protects the Company’s information, assets, and shipboard systems by safeguarding confidentiality, integrity, and availability. It establishes accountability, promotes awareness, and ensures continuity of operations in the event of cyber incidents.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Cyber Risk Management

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Company identifies and assesses IT and OT systems that could impact operations if disrupted. Risk management includes recognizing threats and vulnerabilities, implementing protection and detection measures, and ensuring that networks, access control, and communication boundaries remain secure.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Governance and Leadership

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Top Management provides resources and direction for maintaining cyber resilience. It enforces cybersecurity policies, monitors awareness levels, conducts training, and promotes adherence to preventive practices while reviewing performance and improving procedures continuously.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Controls and Preventive Measures

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Cyber protection is achieved through secured configurations, controlled network access, restricted use of removable media, and defined privileges for remote and local access. Training, equipment disposal procedures, and maintenance of protective software support the overall defense framework.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Incident Response and Recovery

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: In the event of a cyber incident, the Company ensures prompt detection, reporting, and containment. Recovery procedures restore affected systems and data using backups and contingency plans, ensuring that shipboard and shore-based operations continue without major disruption.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 20 defines the Company’s Cybersecurity management system. It establishes leadership, risk assessment, prevention, and recovery measures to safeguard IT/OT systems, ensuring business continuity, data protection, and sustained operational security across all activities.

chapters.title: Chapter 3 — Company and Shipboard Organization, Responsibilities and Authorities

slides.title: Chapter 3 — Company and Shipboard Organization, Responsibilities and Authorities
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Company Organization

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company maintains a structured organization of qualified managers, engineers, and officers dedicated to safe and efficient fleet operations. Departments collaborate to ensure compliance with HSQE standards, resource adequacy, and continuous personnel training for optimal performance.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Shore Responsibilities

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Managers and key shore personnel coordinate departmental activities, verify SMS implementation, and maintain safe working conditions. They lead by example, review performance, monitor audits, and promote proactive participation and continuous improvement within all departments.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Shipboard Organization

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Each vessel follows an onboard organization chart defining ranks, authority, and lines of communication. All seagoing personnel understand their responsibilities and are accountable for safety, environmental protection, and adherence to Company policies during daily operations.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Shipboard Safety Organization

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: The Safety Organization onboard ensures proper hazard control and risk management. Masters, Officers, and crew share responsibility for maintaining safe work environments, conducting inspections, reporting unsafe acts, and ensuring all operations follow approved safety procedures.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Safety and Environmental Committee

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Each vessel holds monthly Safety Committee meetings to review shipboard safety, training effectiveness, and incident trends. Minutes and recommendations are distributed to all personnel and forwarded to the Company for review and follow-up actions to enhance HSQE performance.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 3 explains how Company and shipboard structures define authority, communication, and responsibility. It highlights leadership, accountability, and shared safety culture between shore and ship to ensure effective management and continuous improvement.

chapters.title: Chapter 4 — Designated Person Ashore (DPA) / Quality Management Representative (QMR)

slides.title: Chapter 4 — Designated Person Ashore (DPA) / Quality Management Representative (QMR)
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Function and Role

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Designated Person Ashore (DPA) ensures the effective development, implementation, and maintenance of the Company’s Safety Management System. The DPA monitors the HSQE aspects of all fleet operations, ensuring compliance with international regulations and internal safety standards.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Quality Management Responsibilities

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Quality Management Representative (QMR) oversees the quality and customer satisfaction elements of ship management. This role ensures that performance indicators are tracked, quality procedures are implemented correctly, and corrective actions are initiated when required.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Combined Designation

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Within the Company’s SMS, the term “DPA” encompasses both DPA and QMR functions. This integrated approach streamlines management control, improves communication, and maintains alignment between safety, environmental, and quality objectives across the fleet.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Deputy DPA

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: A Deputy DPA is formally appointed to perform all duties in the absence of the DPA. This ensures continuity of oversight and uninterrupted safety management support. The Deputy DPA holds equal authority to act on safety and quality matters when delegated.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Reporting Line

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The DPA reports directly to the General Manager, maintaining an open channel between Company leadership and operational personnel. This direct reporting relationship ensures that safety and quality issues receive prompt attention at the highest management level.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 4 outlines the duties and authority of the DPA and QMR, emphasizing their combined responsibility for implementing and monitoring the Safety Management System. It highlights continuity through the Deputy DPA role and the direct reporting link to top management.

slides.title: Chapter 5 — Master’s Responsibility and Authority
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Qualifications and General Role

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Master acts as the Company’s representative onboard, holding ultimate responsibility for the ship’s safety, crew welfare, and environmental protection. He must possess valid certificates, leadership ability, sound judgment, and the capacity to manage, motivate, and train crew effectively in compliance with Company and international standards.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Operational and Administrative Duties

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Master ensures the safe, efficient, and cost-effective operation of the vessel. Duties include voyage preparation, cargo safety, maintenance oversight, and compliance with international conventions. He must maintain accurate records, submit reports promptly, and monitor crew certification, welfare, and discipline.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ HSQE and Crew Motivation

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Master implements Company policies and SMS procedures onboard, ensuring that safety and environmental standards are upheld. He promotes crew participation in safety practices, leads Safety Committee meetings, and provides guidance to ensure continuous improvement and HSQE awareness among all personnel.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Navigational and Technical Oversight

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: The Master ensures safe navigation, compliance with COLREGS, and effective bridge team management. He verifies vessel readiness before departure, supervises inspections and maintenance, and confirms all lifesaving and firefighting equipment are operational, maintaining the ship in a state of readiness.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Authority, Communication, and Reporting

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Master maintains direct communication with Company Managers, the DPA, and the General Manager. He exercises overriding authority in all matters affecting safety and pollution prevention, empowered to take any action—regardless of commercial impact—to safeguard life, property, and the environment.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 5 defines the Master’s ultimate authority and responsibility for safe vessel operation. It outlines qualifications, duties, communication, and decision-making power, emphasizing leadership, safety culture, and the obligation to protect people, property, and the environment.

slides.title: Chapter 6.1 — Resources and Personnel (Crew)
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Principles

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company ensures that all seafarers are properly qualified, experienced, medically fit, and competent to perform their assigned duties. Strict selection procedures, training programs, and appraisal systems are in place to verify that every crew member meets Flag State and industry standards while promoting safety, professionalism, and motivation.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Resource Management and Planning

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Human resource planning ensures adequate manning levels on all vessels. Preference is given to personnel with prior Company experience, promoting familiarity with procedures and culture. Continuous development programs train seafarers to apply the SMS, safeguard health, and align with Company objectives for safety and environmental protection.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Recruitment and Familiarization

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Company conducts recruitment directly or through approved manning agencies under defined standards. Pre-joining familiarization ensures officers and ratings understand vessel-specific systems, emergency duties, and Company policies. No person under 18 years of age may be employed or permitted to work onboard.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Training, Appraisal, and Development

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Training programs—ashore and onboard—cover technical skills, safety practices, and leadership competence. Regular appraisals measure performance and identify training needs. Promotion is based on merit, experience, and demonstrated ability to uphold SMS principles and operational excellence.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Conduct, Discipline, and Equal Opportunity

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Company applies progressive discipline to correct behavior while ensuring fairness and due process. It enforces a strict zero-tolerance policy against discrimination, harassment, bullying, sexual assault, or sexual harassment. Diversity, dignity, and equal opportunity are core values upheld in all shipboard and shore operations.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 6.1 defines the Company’s policies for crew selection, training, appraisal, and discipline. It ensures competent, well-trained, and motivated personnel while fostering fairness, equality, and a safe working environment across the fleet.

slides.title: Chapter 6.2 — Resources and Personnel (Shore)
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Requirements

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: This chapter defines the procedures for selecting, appointing, and managing qualified and competent shore personnel. The Company employs sufficient staff to support all managed vessels, ensuring HSQE processes are efficiently implemented and personnel conditions of employment are properly administered.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Qualification and Validation

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Company verifies all declared qualifications, certificates, and employment records for accuracy and authenticity. Continuous professional development is maintained through training, participation in seminars, and engagement in industry forums to preserve and expand staff competence.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Appraisal and Development

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: A structured appraisal system evaluates the performance and competence of shore employees. It identifies training needs and development opportunities, ensuring that personnel remain capable of meeting organizational objectives while enhancing their professional growth.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Retention and Motivation

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: The Company promotes continuity by retaining key staff and fostering job satisfaction through merit-based recognition. Equal opportunities are provided to all employees regardless of gender, origin, or belief, maintaining a professional and inclusive work environment.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Training and Support

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Training needs are monitored and addressed through refresher courses, internal programs, and mentorship. Shore personnel are encouraged to participate in workshops and conferences, reinforcing knowledge exchange and alignment with evolving industry standards.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 6.2 outlines the policies for managing shore personnel. It ensures adequate staffing, competence verification, performance evaluation, and continuous development to maintain a motivated, skilled, and reliable workforce supporting fleet operations.

slides.title: Chapter 6.3 — Maritime Labour Convention (MLC) Compliance
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Overview

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Maritime Labour Convention (MLC 2006) establishes minimum global standards for seafarers’ working and living conditions. It safeguards health, safety, welfare, and fair treatment while ensuring equal rights and consistent protection across the shipping industry.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Structure and Purpose

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The MLC comprises Articles, Regulations, and a Code divided into mandatory (Part A) and guideline (Part B) sections. It defines the responsibilities of Flag Administrations, Companies, and seafarers to maintain compliance and continuous improvement in labor standards.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Areas of Application

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Convention addresses sixteen core areas including age, certification, manning, hours of work, accommodation, food, health protection, medical care, and social security. Each area must be implemented through Company procedures and verified by the Competent Authority.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Documentation and Certification

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Each vessel must carry a Maritime Labour Certificate and a Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance (DMLC). These documents confirm that the Company meets all required standards and that shipboard conditions are inspected, monitored, and certified by authorities.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Implementation and Oversight

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Company integrates MLC requirements into its Safety Management System to prevent substandard conditions and support seafarers’ rights. Compliance is maintained through audits, inspections, and regular reviews ensuring welfare, safety, and professional dignity for all crew members.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 6.3 outlines the Company’s full adherence to the MLC 2006, ensuring that all seafarers enjoy safe, fair, and humane working conditions. It formalizes welfare, certification, and compliance controls under international maritime labor standards.

chapters.title: Chapter 6.4 — Maritime Labour Convention (MLC) — Detailed Requirements

slides.title: Chapter 6.4 — Maritime Labour Convention (MLC) — Detailed Requirements
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Overview

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Maritime Labour Convention (MLC 2006) establishes uniform international standards for the health, safety, and welfare of seafarers. It aims to prevent substandard working conditions, ensure fair treatment, and create a consistent legal framework applicable to all seafaring nations.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Structure and Implementation

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The MLC consists of Articles, Regulations, and a Code divided into mandatory (Part A) and guideline (Part B) sections. It is organized under five Titles covering minimum requirements, employment conditions, accommodation and welfare, medical care, and compliance with enforcement measures.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Key Compliance Areas

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Sixteen core areas are addressed, including minimum age, medical certification, qualifications, working hours, manning levels, accommodation, food and catering, medical care, complaint procedures, and wage protection. Each requirement must be implemented and verified through the Company’s SMS and DMLC.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Certification and Documentation

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Each vessel must maintain a valid Maritime Labour Certificate and Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance (DMLC). These confirm that onboard conditions meet the Convention’s standards and that the Company operates under verified procedures approved by the competent authority.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Monitoring and Continuous Improvement

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Company ensures ongoing MLC compliance through audits, internal reviews, and inspections. Feedback from crew and authorities is used to enhance welfare, working conditions, and operational integrity, ensuring that MLC principles are consistently upheld across the fleet.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 6.4 defines the detailed MLC requirements governing seafarers’ living and working conditions. It outlines the regulatory structure, compliance areas, and certification process that ensure fair treatment, welfare, and safety onboard all Company vessels.

chapters.title: Chapter 7.1 — General Provisions for Key Shipboard Operations

slides.title: Chapter 7.1 — General Provisions for Key Shipboard Operations
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Safe and Compliant Operations

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: All shipboard activities must be conducted safely, efficiently, and in full compliance with Company procedures, applicable laws, and international regulations. Each operation follows planned steps designed to prevent incidents and ensure safe working practices at all times.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Risk Identification and Control

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Company identifies all shipboard operations with potential hazards and applies risk management controls to reduce or eliminate them. These include safe work permits, qualified personnel assignment, and procedures ensuring that no task proceeds under unsafe conditions.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Process Planning and Documentation

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Processes are planned and developed to meet service realization requirements. Managers prepare or revise operational instructions considering new regulations, audit findings, and feedback from vessels. Approved changes are documented and distributed under controlled conditions.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Review, Approval, and Amendment Control

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: The General Manager reviews and approves all new or amended procedures. The DPA updates the SMS accordingly and distributes controlled copies to all holders, while Masters confirm receipt and destroy obsolete versions to maintain procedural accuracy.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Master’s Authority

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The SMS never restricts the Master’s overriding authority to take action necessary to protect life, property, and the environment. When external instructions conflict with Company procedures, the Master must follow SMS requirements or seek specific clarification from the office.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.1 defines how key shipboard operations are planned, documented, and controlled to maintain safety and compliance. It reinforces the Master’s ultimate authority and the Company’s commitment to continuous improvement through effective risk and document management.

chapters.title: Chapter 7.10 — Health, Hygiene, and Medical Issues

slides.title: Chapter 7.10 — Health, Hygiene, and Medical Issues
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Health and Safety Principles

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company is committed to maintaining a healthy, hygienic, and safe working environment for all employees and crew. Risks are prevented or minimized through proper planning, equipment maintenance, and continuous training in occupational health and hygiene.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Responsibilities and Objectives

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Management ensures that work is organized and performed with due regard to personal health, hygiene, and safety. Regular inspections, medical checks, and staff familiarization promote awareness of health risks and support the prevention of illness or injury.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Hygiene and Living Conditions

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Cleanliness of accommodation, food storage, and catering areas is maintained to high standards. Routine cleaning, pest control, and safe food-handling practices reduce contamination risks, ensuring healthy living and working conditions onboard.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Medical Care and First Aid

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Each vessel maintains a hospital space, medical locker, and first aid supplies in accordance with MLC and Flag requirements. Trained personnel administer first aid, keep medical records, and arrange telemedical advice or evacuation when necessary.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Health Monitoring and Preventive Actions

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Company evaluates workplace hazards such as noise, temperature, and chemical exposure. Preventive actions include PPE use, ventilation control, and regular safety briefings to ensure long-term crew well-being and regulatory compliance.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.10 outlines Company procedures to protect crew health through hygiene control, preventive safety measures, and medical readiness. It promotes continuous monitoring and improvement of living, catering, and occupational conditions onboard.

slides.title: Chapter 7.11 — Fatigue
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Definition and Significance

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: Fatigue is a reduction in mental or physical performance caused by lack of rest, long working hours, or disruption of natural sleep patterns. It affects alertness, coordination, and decision-making, posing a serious risk to shipboard safety and efficiency.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Causes of Fatigue

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Fatigue may result from inadequate sleep, monotonous work, extended watch schedules, or environmental factors such as noise, vibration, and stress. Both physical exertion and emotional strain can reduce concentration and increase the likelihood of human error.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Effects and Identification

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Fatigue leads to slower reaction times, poor judgment, irritability, and decreased communication efficiency. Masters and officers must monitor crew performance, recognize warning signs early, and take corrective action before safety is compromised.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Prevention and Control Measures

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Adequate rest hours, proper scheduling, and work rotation are essential to prevent fatigue. Regular breaks, balanced nutrition, and maintaining quiet rest areas contribute to alertness and overall well-being. Crew members must report excessive tiredness without fear of penalty.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Hours of Rest Compliance

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: All personnel must comply with the STCW and MLC rest-hour requirements. The minimum rest is 10 hours in any 24-hour period and 77 hours in any seven-day period. Records of work and rest hours are maintained and verified during audits and inspections.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.11 defines fatigue as a safety-critical risk affecting alertness and decision-making. It establishes rest-hour requirements, monitoring, and preventive practices ensuring that all seafarers remain fit, alert, and compliant with international maritime standards.

slides.title: Chapter 7.2 — Navigation
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Navigation Policy

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The primary objective of the Company’s navigation policy is to safeguard life, property, cargo, and the marine environment. All navigation is performed in accordance with international conventions, national regulations, and Company procedures ensuring safe, compliant voyages.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Bridge Team Management (BTM)

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Navigation follows the Bridge Team Management (BTM) concept to eliminate single-person errors. Officers cooperate as a team, maintain continuous situational awareness, and support each other in decision-making to uphold navigational safety.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Officer Competence and Equipment Knowledge

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: All deck officers must be fully familiar with Company navigation procedures, COLREGS, ship maneuvering characteristics, and navigational equipment operation. Regular training and performance reviews ensure competence and professional readiness.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Chart and Publication Management

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: The Company’s contracted chart agents supply up-to-date ENCs and navigational publications. The designated officer maintains chart corrections and ensures all required materials are available and current before and during every voyage.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Master’s Responsibility and Voyage Planning

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Master holds full responsibility for the vessel’s safe navigation. Passage plans are prepared and approved prior to departure, incorporating weather, traffic, and vessel condition. Safety always takes precedence over commercial or schedule pressures.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.2 outlines the Company’s navigation policy emphasizing teamwork, competence, and strict adherence to procedures. It reinforces that navigational safety and environmental protection remain the Master’s highest responsibilities at all times.

slides.title: Chapter 7.3 — Mooring and Anchoring Operations
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Policy and General Principles

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: All Company vessels must be equipped with mooring and anchoring systems that meet current industry and regulatory standards. Equipment must be properly maintained, certified, and suitable for the vessel’s size and operational requirements, ensuring safe mooring under all conditions.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Equipment Maintenance and Inspection

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Company performs periodic inspections and maintenance of all mooring and anchoring gear. Reviews assess equipment performance, identify areas for improvement, and ensure modifications follow the latest industry best practices and safety recommendations.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Personnel Responsibilities and Training

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Mooring and anchoring operations are inherently hazardous and must only be carried out under competent supervision. All personnel involved receive appropriate training, follow SMS procedures, and remain alert to snap-back zones, load risks, and communication signals during operations.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Operational Procedures and Controls

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Each operation must be pre-planned, assigning specific duties to responsible officers and crew. The Master and Chief Officer verify the readiness of all mooring lines, tails, shackles, and anchors. Standard checklists and permits are used to control risks before, during, and after operations.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Continuous Review and Compliance

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Company continually reviews mooring and anchoring practices through audits and incident feedback. Lessons learned are integrated into future procedures, ensuring safe practices, compliance with terminal criteria, and adherence to evolving international standards.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.3 defines the Company’s policy for mooring and anchoring operations. It establishes equipment standards, crew training, procedural control, and continuous improvement to maintain safe and compliant operations across the fleet.

slides.title: Chapter 7.4 — Engine Room Operations
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Provisions

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: All engineering operations must be carried out safely, efficiently, and in strict compliance with international regulations, manufacturer’s instructions, and the Company’s Safety Management System. Preventive maintenance and condition-based monitoring ensure machinery reliability and operational readiness.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Chief Engineer’s Oversight

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Chief Engineer holds full responsibility for all engine room activities. He ensures that maintenance schedules, operational checks, and repairs are performed as planned. Daily standing orders, inspections, and test routines maintain system integrity and promote safety awareness among all crew members.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Superintendent and Technical Management

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Superintendent Engineers verify the implementation of engine room procedures during ship visits, ensuring conformance with established Company standards. The Technical Manager reviews audit results and inspection records to confirm that maintenance quality and safety levels are consistently upheld.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Safety, Emergencies, and Best Practice

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Engineering operations must always follow the Code of Safe Working Practices (COSWP) and the maker’s guidelines. Crew members are required to perform shutdown and alarm tests at defined intervals, ensuring readiness for any operational or emergency condition within the engine room.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Verification and Documentation

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Verification procedures ensure that maintenance standards and safety protocols are properly followed. Forms and audit checklists support the tracking of performance, providing transparency and accountability across shipboard and shore-based engineering functions.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.4 establishes the foundation for safe, compliant, and well-documented engine room operations. It emphasizes preventive maintenance, procedural discipline, and verification by Chief Engineers, Superintendents, and Technical Managers to maintain consistent engineering excellence.

chapters.title: Chapter 7.5 — Bulk Cargo Handling and Ballast Operations

slides.title: Chapter 7.5 — Bulk Cargo Handling and Ballast Operations
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Policy

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: Cargo and ballast operations must be conducted safely, efficiently, and in compliance with the Company’s SMS, the IMSBC Code, and international regulations. Masters and Chief Officers are responsible for ensuring safe planning, supervision, and documentation during all stages of operations.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Cargo Operations and Precautions

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Before loading, cargo holds must be clean, dry, and inspected. Officers verify cargo information, reactivity, and compatibility while ensuring correct stowage and trimming. Snap-back zones, lighting safety, and restricted entry areas are strictly enforced throughout operations.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Ballast Water Management

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Ballast operations are performed according to the approved Ballast Water Management Plan (BWMP). Officers monitor stability, stress, and ballast sequences, preventing hydraulic shock and ensuring tanks are inspected, vented, and maintained under safe conditions.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Ship-to-Ship (STS) and Specialized Cargoes

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: STS cargo transfers, lightering, or transshipments follow strict Company procedures. Weather, swell, and lighting limitations are observed. Specialized or hazardous bulk cargoes are handled per the IMSBC Code with continuous supervision and environmental precautions.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Documentation, Monitoring, and Records

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: All cargo and ballast activities are logged in Company forms and checklists. Loading computers, tank soundings, and ballast treatment systems are verified at each stage. Records ensure full traceability and compliance with Flag and Port State requirements.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.5 defines procedures for bulk cargo and ballast operations under the Company’s SMS. It emphasizes planning, hazard control, ballast management, and precise documentation to maintain safe, compliant, and efficient shipboard operations.

slides.title: Chapter 7.6 — Environmental Procedures
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Compliance Framework

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company ensures full compliance with MARPOL, OPA-90, and other environmental conventions through its Safety Management System. All ships follow legal and industry requirements to control discharges, emissions, and waste management processes.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Pollution Prevention Measures

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Operations involving oily bilge water, sludge, sewage, or garbage are carried out under approved procedures and recorded in official logs. All discharges to sea, land, or air are monitored, treated, and managed to prevent pollution and protect the marine environment.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Air Emission and Energy Control

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Company complies with MARPOL Annex VI requirements, maintaining certified engines, monitoring SOx and NOx emissions, and recording use of ozone-depleting substances. Energy performance is optimized through continuous monitoring, following ISO 50001 principles.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Waste, Ballast, and Recycling

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Ballast water operations follow approved management plans, ensuring treatment and safe exchange. Waste segregation, garbage control, and ship recycling are performed under verified procedures, supporting sustainability and compliance with the Inventory of Hazardous Materials (IHM).

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Environmental Management and Review

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Environmental performance is reviewed through audits, inspections, and crew feedback. The Company applies the Plan–Do–Check–Act model to identify risks, set objectives, and enhance awareness, achieving measurable improvements in environmental protection and energy efficiency.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.6 establishes the Company’s environmental protection framework, aligning MARPOL compliance with ISO 14001 and ISO 50001 standards. It ensures pollution prevention, emission control, and continuous environmental performance improvement across all operations.

slides.title: Chapter 7.7 — Drug and Alcohol (D&A) Control
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Policy Overview

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company’s Drug and Alcohol (D&A) policy applies to all seafarers, contractors, visitors, and personnel onboard. It prohibits the possession, use, or distribution of drugs and restricts alcohol consumption to approved limits, ensuring that all personnel remain fit for duty and free from impairment.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Purpose and Objectives

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The D&A policy aims to prevent accidents, promote safe working conditions, and maintain professional integrity. It defines prevention measures, testing programs, and disciplinary actions to eliminate the influence of drugs and alcohol in shipboard operations.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Alcohol Consumption Control

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Alcohol is strictly limited to one 330 ml beer (<3.5% ABV) per person per day, for a maximum of two days per week, and only with the Master’s approval. Consumption is prohibited within four hours of watchkeeping or duty, and entirely banned within 24 hours before entering U.S. waters.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Drug Prohibition and Testing

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Possession or use of illegal drugs is a dismissible offence. The Company performs pre-employment, random, and post-incident drug tests in accordance with international standards. All test results are confidential but strictly enforced to protect personnel and operational safety.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Awareness and Disciplinary Measures

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: The Company promotes awareness through training and communication to prevent D&A misuse. Violations are subject to disciplinary action, including dismissal and possible legal prosecution. Preventive education reinforces responsibility, self-control, and adherence to Company values.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.7 outlines the Company’s strict policy against drug and alcohol misuse. It defines responsibilities, preventive measures, and enforcement procedures ensuring safety, professionalism, and compliance with maritime and labor regulations.

slides.title: Chapter 7.8 — Communications
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Principles

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: Effective communication is essential for the safe and efficient management of ships and shore operations. All Company personnel must ensure clarity, accuracy, and timeliness in both routine and emergency communications to support safe navigation and continuous operational awareness.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Communication Scope

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: This procedure defines communication protocols between the Company and managed ships, internal Company departments, external stakeholders, and third parties. It also covers shipboard communications, distress alerts, danger messages, and ship reporting requirements under international conventions.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Confidentiality and Control

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Personnel involved in preparing or handling messages must preserve the confidentiality of all Company information. Sensitive data, including reports and correspondence, must be transmitted through authorized channels and handled in accordance with regulatory and internal requirements.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Roles and Responsibilities

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Shore management, Masters, and Officers share responsibility for accurate and prompt communication. The Company provides training and technology to support effective coordination, ensuring all communication systems are functional, tested, and properly maintained.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Emergency and Safety Communications

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Distress, urgency, and safety messages are handled per GMDSS procedures using approved equipment and frequencies. Radio logs, backup power sources, and equipment checks ensure reliability and readiness during emergencies and critical shipboard operations.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.8 establishes procedures for all ship-to-shore, internal, and emergency communications. It ensures accuracy, confidentiality, and compliance with international regulations to maintain safe, reliable, and efficient information exchange across the Company’s operations.

chapters.title: Chapter 7.9 — Procedures for Safe Work Performance

slides.title: Chapter 7.9 — Procedures for Safe Work Performance
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ General Purpose and Responsibilities

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: Managers and Masters are responsible for implementing safe working practices, ensuring all crew are briefed, trained, and supervised. The system promotes hazard identification, teamwork, and proactive safety culture through structured daily planning and risk assessment.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Daily Work Plan Meetings

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: The Master holds daily meetings to review scheduled jobs, hazards, PPE requirements, and interdepartmental coordination. Each meeting confirms that resources, spares, and competent personnel are available, while preventing conflicts between simultaneous shipboard tasks.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Tool Box Talks (TBT)

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Tool Box Talks are short safety discussions held before any job. They allow team members to identify hazards, agree on control measures, and confirm task understanding. These informal sessions strengthen safety awareness and encourage open communication among crew.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Permit-to-Work (PTW) System

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: High-risk jobs such as hot work, enclosed space entry, and electrical or pressure-related work require formal permits. The PTW defines the scope, safety checks, and authorization levels, ensuring that tasks are performed only under controlled and approved conditions.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Continuous Monitoring and Improvement

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: All permits, checklists, and reports are reviewed to verify compliance and lessons learned. The Company regularly evaluates the effectiveness of its safety systems, updating procedures and training to maintain the highest operational safety standards.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 7.9 defines the Company’s structured approach to safe work performance. It establishes daily work planning, Tool Box Talks, and the Permit-to-Work system as essential tools for risk control, teamwork, and continuous safety improvement onboard.

slides.title: Chapter 8 — Emergency Preparedness
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Scope

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company maintains an integrated system of Emergency Response Plans (ERP) covering all potential incidents that may affect personnel, the ship, the environment, or cargo. Each vessel implements these plans alongside statutory documents such as SOPEP and NT-VRP.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Initial Assessment

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Upon an emergency, the Master must immediately assess the situation, identify risks, and determine the need for external assistance. Priorities are clearly defined: protect life first, then the ship, the environment, and finally the cargo. The assessment establishes the foundation for all response actions.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Reporting and Communication

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: The Master must ensure prompt reporting to the Company, coastal and port authorities, and other relevant contacts. Reports must include situation details, damage extent, assistance required, and ongoing corrective actions, ensuring transparency and coordination throughout the event.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Emergency Response Actions

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: The Company’s Emergency Response Team (ERT) coordinates with the vessel to manage incidents effectively. Responsibilities include crew welfare, documentation, contact with external agencies, and media handling. All actions are logged to maintain traceability and post-incident review capability.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Training, Drills, and Evaluation

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Both shore-based and shipboard personnel conduct regular drills, exercises, and training to maintain readiness. Evaluation of these drills identifies lessons learned and supports continuous improvement of the ERP system to strengthen preparedness across all operational scenarios.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 8 defines the Company’s system for effective emergency preparedness and response. It establishes clear priorities, reporting channels, and coordination procedures to protect life, property, and the environment through planning, training, and continuous improvement.

chapters.title: Chapter 9 — Reporting, Root Cause Analysis, and Investigation of Non-Conformities, Incidents, and Near Misses

slides.title: Chapter 9 — Reporting, Root Cause Analysis, and Investigation of Non-Conformities, Incidents, and Near Misses
slides.text: ✅ Summary

slides.title: Section 1
slides.text: 1️⃣ Purpose and Objectives

slides.title: Section 2
slides.text: The Company’s reporting system ensures that all undesired events—accidents, incidents, non-conformities, near-misses, and unsafe acts—are promptly identified, reported, and analyzed. Its goal is to eliminate or reduce risk to the lowest reasonably practicable level through structured root cause analysis.

slides.title: Section 3
slides.text: 2️⃣ Responsibilities and Just Culture

slides.title: Section 4
slides.text: Management, Masters, and Officers share responsibility for promoting a “Just Culture,” encouraging open reporting without fear of punishment. Errors or omissions are treated as learning opportunities unless caused by negligence or willful violation of established procedures.

slides.title: Section 5
slides.text: 3️⃣ Reporting and Investigation Process

slides.title: Section 6
slides.text: Undesired events are documented using standardized Company forms. The Master initiates immediate notification to the office, secures evidence, and prevents recurrence. The DPA assigns investigators who gather facts, analyze causes, and recommend corrective and preventive actions.

slides.title: Section 7
slides.text: 4️⃣ Root Cause Analysis and Corrective Actions

slides.title: Section 8
slides.text: Investigations identify direct, underlying, and root causes through structured methodologies such as DNV M-SCAT. Corrective and preventive actions are developed, implemented, and verified for effectiveness before case closure, ensuring lessons are integrated into Company procedures.

slides.title: Section 9
slides.text: 5️⃣ Continuous Improvement and Records

slides.title: Section 10
slides.text: Investigation reports and statistics are reviewed during management meetings to identify trends and improvement areas. The Company maintains transparent records of all non-conformities and uses findings to strengthen the SMS, enhance training, and prevent recurrence.

slides.title: Section 12
slides.text: Chapter 9 defines the Company’s system for reporting, analyzing, and learning from all undesired events. It promotes transparency, continuous improvement, and a Just Culture to prevent recurrence and maintain high safety and quality standards across all operations.
